meanings.definition: A person who uses sensationalism in writing or reporting.
meanings.sent1: The sensationalist wrote a story with exaggerated details to attract more readers.
meanings.sent2: The newspaper hired a sensationalist to increase their circulation.
meanings.sent3: The sensationalist's article was so over-the-top that it seemed like a work of fiction.
meanings.sent4: Her reputation as a sensationalist made her stories seem larger than life.
meanings.sent5: The sensationalist's headlines were always attention-grabbing and dramatic.

meanings.definition: A style of writing or reporting that emphasizes shocking or lurid details.
meanings.sent1: The tabloid's sensationalist approach to news often included scandalous headlines.
meanings.sent2: Readers were drawn to the sensationalist style of the article due to its dramatic content.
meanings.sent3: The sensationalist nature of the news made it hard to distinguish fact from fiction.
meanings.sent4: The sensationalist headlines screamed for attention from the newsstands.
meanings.sent5: The sensationalist tone of the article left a lasting impact on the readers.

meanings.sent1: The sensationalist nature of the story made it hard to believe.
meanings.sent2: The sensationalist headlines grabbed the reader's attention immediately.
meanings.sent3: Her sensationalist style of writing added excitement to the otherwise dull news.
meanings.sent4: The movie's plot was so sensationalist that it felt like a rollercoaster ride.
meanings.sent5: The sensationalist approach of the journalist made the story more intriguing.
